Award.AwardTitle: Student interactions with and learning from mastery-inspired online activities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses an important and widespread deficiency in current online homework systems that may be reducing the success rate of students interested in STEM. It will introduce an evolving type of online homework activity that incorporates results from cognitive science and multimedia learning on the importance of practice, feedback and worked examples to enable student learning. A key feature of these activities is that students are given as much (or as little) practice and support as they need to master the concepts in the homework. These activities will be incorporated into an introductory physics course designed for students that are concerned about their ability to succeed in Engineering at Illinois. Results from this work will serve as a guide for the development of a complete set of materials to transform the teaching of introductory physics and improve student outcomes.

The goal of this project is to advance our understanding of the conditions under which a mastery style online homework activity can improve student learning. Clinical studies have shown that providing students multiple opportunities to demonstrate mastery, with animated and narrated solutions between attempts provides significantly improved learning compared with traditional multi-attempt homework. However, in-situ studies have shown the mastery requirement can be frustrating to students. This project will investigate the impact that improvements in the messaging, delivery and content of the activities have on student experience and learning. In particular, students will begin with an activity that allows them to self-identify the advantages of the new approach. The content will be modified based on student data to ensure that the mastery goals are attainable. Students will also be given partial credit for partial mastery. Understanding the impact of these changes will provide guidelines for creating and implementing effective mastery activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addresses an important and widespread deficiency in current online homework systems that may be reducing the success rate of students interested in STEM.  In particular, this project introduced a new type of online homework activity that incorporates results from cognitive science and multimedia learning on the importance of practice, feedback and worked examples to enable student learning.  A key feature of these activities is that students are given as much (or little) practice and support as they need to master the concepts in the homework. These activities were incorporated into an introductory physics course designed for students that are concerned about their ability to succeed in Engineering at Illinois.  Careful analysis of the student interactions with these activities allowed us to advance our understanding the conditions under which a mastery style online homework activity can improve student learning.  Clinical studies have shown that providing students multiple opportunities to demonstrate mastery, with animated and narrated solutions between attempts provides significantly improved learning compared with traditional multi attempt homework.  However, in-situ studies have shown the mastery requirement can also lead to frustration. By making improvements in the messaging, delivery and content of the activities we were able to significantly reduce the student and improve their success rate.

The first significant result is the importance of messaging so students understand the motivation for the new format.  During the first recitation section of the semester, students were asked to identify the advantages and disadvantages of several online homework options including traditional immediate feedback homework, and homework that included help videos. Through this process they discovered how the mastery format incorporates the best aspects of both methods. The first year this was facilitated with members from the Physics Education Research Group, and similar results were obtained in subsequent years when the activity was facilitated the course TAs.  The second significant result is the importance of providing the appropriate level of scaffolding so that students can succeed in mastering the content.  Analysis of student interactions with the material identified some levels that were simply too difficult for a large fraction of students to master.  Adding additional intermediate or supplementary levels significantly improved the mastery rate, without significantly improving the students studying time.  An important question for future research will be understanding to what extent the step size of the levels is universal, and to what extend it depends on the student population. An important corollary to this result is the importance of having consistency between the different activities within a given level.  Indeed, a common source of poor mastery rates was inconsistency in the skills needed to complete different activities in the same level. Figure 1 shows the effect adding a supplementary level had on one particularly difficult week.  The mastery rate increased from 34% to 70%, and the average time needed to complete the activity decreased from 30 minutes to 20 minutes.

Most importantly, we have documented that mastery-based online activities can play an important role in helping students gain competency in core skills essential for passing introductory physics.  However, as with many learning activities, the implementation is important.  We have developed a standardized analysis of student interactions with these activities that can identify levels that are problematic so that they can be improved through an iterative process. 

The research performed under this grant reaffirms the important role that mastery style online homework can have on student learning.  In addition, it identifies several rules that should be followed when developing this type of activity, including methods to identify any deficits in the implementation.
